statement.tex: %text Write a unit vector in the direction of $\ora{a}=\vector{2}{-6}{3}$. %

step.context: %text If $\ora{u}=\vector{u_1}{u_2}{u_3}$ is a unit vector, what is true about $u_1$, $u_2$ and $u_3$? %
step.reason: %text If $\ora{u}$ is a unit vector, it means its magnitude is $1$. ie. $|\ora{u}|=1$. Therefore, % \sqrt{u_1^2+u_2^2+u_3^2}=1 \implies u_1^2+u_2^2+u_3^2=1 \\ %text Note: % \begin{align} &u_1=u_2=u_3=1 \\ \implies &|\ora{u}|=\sqrt{u_1^2+u_2^2+u_3^2} \\ \implies &|\ora{u}|=\sqrt{1+1+1}=\sqrt{3} \end{align}

step.context: %text If a vector is multiplied by a scalar, what is{\bf always} true about the resulting vector? %
step.tex: %text It has the same direction as the original vector. %
step.reason: %text If a vector is multiplied by a scalar, all it does is produce a new vector pointing in the exact same direction. This new vector may be of greater, less or the same magnitude when compared with the original vector. % \begin{align} \ora{v}\cdot \lambda = \ora{w} \implies |\ora{v}|=\lambda|\ora{w}| \end{align} \\ %text (where $\lambda$ is a scalar). %
